liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian government says it has airlifted 255 more people from Israel to Dubai, in the first leg of a journey back to Australia. "More than 1,200 Australians previously registered have now left Israel and the Occupied Palestinian Territories, including more than 400 Australians and their families on four Australian Government assisted-departure flights," Foreign Minister Penny Wong says. "We continue to consider options to assist Australians who want to leave Israel or the Occupied Palestinian Territories. "We encourage Australians who want to leave to take the first option available, do not wait for a different option." The latest group of evacuees, after the first flights on October 13, flew out of Ben Gurion Airport on two Air Force planes and a charter plane. The federal government says it has secured flights to Australia for those Australians who landed in Dubai, and there are plans for more government-supported flights out of Tel Aviv later today. A government statement described the situation as "highly challenging and rapidly changing". "Australian nationals and visa holders who wish to leave Israel should ensure they are registered with DFAT via their crisis portal, " Defence Minister Richard Marles says.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 255 more Australians airlifted from Israel

props.alt: Travellers walk through Ben Gurion airport in Israel next to a sign reading "SHELTER".

children.content: Travellers at Ben Gurion airport.
(Reuters)
The Australian government says it has airlifted 255 more people from Israel to Dubai, in the first leg of a journey back to Australia.

"More than 1,200 Australians previously registered have now left Israel and the Occupied Palestinian Territories, including more than 400 Australians and their families on four Australian Government assisted-departure flights," Foreign Minister Penny Wong says.
"We continue to consider options to assist Australians who want to leave Israel or the Occupied Palestinian Territories.
"We encourage Australians who want to leave to take the first option available, do not wait for a different option."
The latest group of evacuees, after the first flights on October 13, flew out of Ben Gurion Airport on two Air Force planes and a charter plane.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The US embassy in Israel has sent an alert citing media reports that the Rafah border crossing between Gaza and Egypt will open at 9am local time (5pm AEDT). "We anticipate that the situation at the Rafah crossing will remain fluid and unpredictable and it is unclear whether, or for how long, travelers will be permitted to transit the crossing," the embassy's statement said. "If you assess it to be safe, you may wish to move closer to the Rafah border crossing â there may be very little notice if the crossing opens and it may only open for a limited time." The opening of the crossing would allow aid into Gaza and allow foreign nationals out of Palestinian territory.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rafah border crossing 'may only open for a limited time'

children.content: The US embassy in Israel has sent an alert citing media reports that the Rafah border crossing between Gaza and Egypt will open at 9am local time (5pm AEDT).

"We anticipate that the situation at the Rafah crossing will remain fluid and unpredictable and it is unclear whether, or for how long, travelers will be permitted to transit the crossing," the embassy's statement said.
"If you assess it to be safe, you may wish to move closer to the Rafah border crossing â there may be very little notice if the crossing opens and it may only open for a limited time."
The opening of the crossing would allow aid into Gaza and allow foreign nationals out of Palestinian territory.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ABC's global affairs correspondent John Lyons has been reporting from Israel for the past week along with Nick Dole, Tom Joyner, Riley Stuart and Orly Halpern and our contacts in Gaza. John Lyons will be joining the blog later today to answer your questions about this war. You can share your questions by hitting the blue leave a comment button at the top of this stream. We'll pass on your questions to John who'll join us from 7:30pm AEDT. In the meantime, here's John's latest column on the biggest winner of this war.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Do you have questions about the Israel-Gaza war? Ask our correspondent John Lyons

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Wallabies great Mark Ella and former Australian senator and Olympic gold medalist Nova Peris spoke about the defeat of the Voice to Parliament proposal this morning in Sydney. Ms Peris said she had shed too many tears about the result on Saturday night, and struggled to hold them back when she met with NRL great Johnathan Thurston at the Sport Australia Hall of Fame event today. "And just seeing Johnathan [Thurston] here today, we looked at each other and had to turn away because it's a bittersweet thing â you're recognised in other ways," Ms Peris said. "But for Australia to turn its back on us, it's hard,"
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'For Australia to turn its back on us, it's hard'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Asked by Liberal MP for Durack Melissa Price if he was committed to Makarrata truth telling and treaty, Mr Albanese acknowledged that some Indigenous Australians were undertaking a week of silence to reflect on the result and that he was for bringing people together. "Makarrata is simply a Yolngu word for coming together after struggle. I think it is a good thing that people come together and I made it very clear on Saturday night that that is my position," he said. Before attacking Mr Dutton for softening his position on constitutional recognition this morning. "I think that that is a reasonable thing to say, and in terms of where we go from here, I note that there has been a change of position again from the opposition when it comes to constitutional recognition. "And the leader of the opposition said during this process in September, 'we went to the last election and a number of elections before that with that as our policy, and that will be our policy going into the next, and again'. "I think it is right and respectful to recognise the Indigenous Australians in the constitution." On a point of order, Manager of Opposition Business in the House Paul Fletcher called on the Mr Albanese to answer the original question on Makarrata truth telling and treaty. Mr Albanese responded by again bringing up Mr Dutton's comments on constitutional recognition of First Nations people. "And today the leader of the opposition has now taken the next step, he is now opposing himself! He's now saying he's opposed to holding a [referendum on] constitutional recognition."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PM claims Dutton 'opposed' to constitutional recognition for Indigenous people

children.content: Asked by Liberal MP for Durack
Melissa Price

if he was committed to Makarrata truth telling and treaty, Mr Albanese acknowledged that some Indigenous Australians were undertaking a week of silence to reflect on the result and that he was for bringing people together.
"Makarrata is simply a Yolngu word for coming together after struggle. I think it is a good thing that people come together and

I made it very clear on Saturday night that that is my position," he said.
Before attacking Mr Dutton for softening his position on constitutional recognition this morning.

"I think that that is a reasonable thing to say, and in terms of where we go from here, I note that there has been a change of position again from the opposition when it comes to constitutional recognition.

"And the leader of the opposition said during this process in September, 'we went to the last election and a number of elections before that with that as our policy, and that will be our policy going into the next, and again'.
"I think it is right and respectful to recognise the Indigenous Australians in the constitution."
Â
On a point of order, Manager of
Â
Opposition Business in the House

called on the Mr Albanese to answer the original question on Makarrata truth telling and treaty.
Mr Albanese responded by again bringing up Mr Dutton's comments on constitutional recognition of First Nations people.
"And today the leader of the opposition has now taken the next step, he is now opposing himself! He's now saying he's opposed to holding a [referendum on] constitutional recognition."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton used the opening question in federal parliament Question Time today to call on the prime minister to "apologise" for taking the Voice to Parliament to a referendum "against advice", as well as for inflation and power price rises. In a later series of questions, Deputy Opposition Leader Sussan Ley described the referendum as "divisive and incompetently managed", asking why Mr Albanese had focused on "inner-city elites": "Why did he refuse to hold a constitutional convention? Why didn't he make the effort to achieve bipartisanship? Why did he waste $450 million of taxpayers' money? Why did he proceed when it was clear his vanity project was going so disastrously wrong?" In response, Mr Albanese said: "Let's be very clear here about what occurred. There was a constitutional convention. There was one established under the former government in 2017. After a process that the former government established under Tony Abbott when he established a process, a working group, who are charged with coming back to the Australian people about what form constitutional recognition should take. "That was after John Howard, of course, and every other leader since promised to promote constitutional recognition. "After a process in 2017, First Nations people through the Uluru Statement from the Heart, those eloquent 440 words, issued an invitation to Australians to walk with them on the form of recognition they sought. That was recognition through a Voice. There were then processes established, including under the former government, The Calma Langton Report and other processes, the joint committee chaired by Patrick Dodson and Julian Leeser, to progress this issue. "I said before the election on a range of occasions, as did both leaders, Scott Morrison and Bill Shorten prior to 2019, that there would be an advance on these issues. I was at Garma when the minister for Indigenous affairs, Ken Wyatt, said there would be a referendum held. I was there in 2019. "What occurred was that I fulfilled that commitment that I made. It was not out of convenience, it was out of conviction. I believe that when you make a commitment, including a commitment to Indigenous people, that it should be fulfilled. "And, I make this point â across remote areas dominated by Indigenous communities, Yes recorded massive support."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Opposition attacks PM for 'divisive' referendum

children.content: Opposition Leader
Â
Peter Dutton
Â

used the opening question in federal parliament Question Time today to call on the prime minister to "apologise" for taking the Voice to Parliament to a referendum "against advice", as well as for inflation and power price rises.
In a later series of questions, Deputy Opposition Leader
Sussan Ley
described the referendum as "divisive and incompetently managed", asking why Mr Albanese had focused on "inner-city elites":

"Why did he refuse to hold a constitutional convention? Why didn't he make the effort to achieve bipartisanship? Why did he waste $450 million of taxpayers' money? Why did he proceed when it was clear his vanity project was going so disastrously wrong?"
In response, Mr Albanese said:

"Let's be very clear here about what occurred. There was a constitutional convention. There was one established under the former government in 2017. After a process that the former government established under Tony Abbott when he established a process, a working group, who are charged with coming back to the Australian people about what form constitutional recognition should take.
"That was after John Howard, of course, and every other leader since promised to promote constitutional recognition.

"After a process in 2017, First Nations people through the Uluru Statement from the Heart, those eloquent 440 words, issued an invitation to Australians to walk with them on the form of recognition they sought. That was recognition through a Voice. There were then processes established, including under the former government, The Calma Langton Report and other processes, the joint committee chaired by Patrick Dodson and Julian Leeser, to progress this issue.

"I said before the election on a range of occasions, as did both leaders, Scott Morrison and Bill Shorten prior to 2019, that there would be an advance on these issues. I was at Garma when the minister for Indigenous affairs, Ken Wyatt, said there would be a referendum held. I was there in 2019.

"What occurred was that I fulfilled that commitment that I made. It was not out of convenience, it was out of conviction. I believe that when you make a commitment, including a commitment to Indigenous people, that it should be fulfilled.
"And, I make this point â across remote areas dominated by Indigenous communities, Yes recorded massive support."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Continuing our series looking at the draft class of 2023, and some of the names you will soon be very familiar with. Next up is Nate Caddy, perhaps the most eye-catching of this year's crop. With his glowing blonde hair and hulking frame, Caddy was impossible to miss on the field as he got around with Vic Metro and the Northern Knights. His footy backed up the attention though, as he starred as a mobile forward who could push up the ground and even have stints in midfield. Caddy's athletic gifts are obvious â his frame is massive, but he covers the ground exceptionally well â and his skills improved as the year progressed. Caddy has worked hard on his goalkicking in particular, and with his impressive tank and work rate is able to get up the field to make his presence felt while still rolling back to hit the scoreboard. He's still a bit untidy, a bit of a bull at a gate sometimes, but clubs will love his infectious energy. Expect Caddy to be a top 10 pick, and expect him to see AFL footy early in 2023 as his body is as ready as a first-year player's can get.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Draft Spotlight â Nate Caddy

children.content: Continuing our series looking at the draft class of 2023, and some of the names you will soon be very familiar with.

Next up is Nate Caddy, perhaps the most eye-catching of this year's crop. With his glowing blonde hair and hulking frame, Caddy was impossible to miss on the field as he got around with Vic Metro and the Northern Knights.
(Getty Images)
His footy backed up the attention though, as he starred as a mobile forward who could push up the ground and even have stints in midfield.
Caddy's athletic gifts are obvious â his frame is massive, but he covers the ground exceptionally well â and his skills improved as the year progressed.

Caddy has worked hard on his goalkicking in particular, and with his impressive tank and work rate is able to get up the field to make his presence felt while still rolling back to hit the scoreboard.
(Getty Images)

He's still a bit untidy, a bit of a bull at a gate sometimes, but clubs will love his infectious energy. Expect Caddy to be a top 10 pick, and expect him to see AFL footy early in 2023 as his body is as ready as a first-year player's can get.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's done! They slipped that one in quietly, but it is all confirmed and signed off. Collingwood have traded pick 34 and a future first round pick to Fremantle for Lachie Schultz. A good deal for Fremantle you'd have to say, smart to back in Collingwood's first-round pick next year being lower than their 19 this year. Certainly can't get any worse. The Pies get their man and strengthen an already premiership-calibre forward line.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lachie Schultz has been traded to Collingwood

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Workers at Chevron's two liquefied natural gas (LNG) facilities in Western Australia's Pilbara region will resume strikes on Thursday as a dispute over pay and conditions continue. Representatives from Chevron and the Offshore Alliance appeared before the Fair Work Commission last week in a bid to work through terms of an in-principle deal for workers at its Wheatstone and Gorgon gas facilities reached in September. But over the weekend, the Offshore Alliance, a collaboration between the Australian Workers' Union and the Maritime Union of Australia, held a secret ballot where 91% of the 410 members that took part supported the strike action. A spokesman from Chevron described the move as "extremely disappointing" and said it went against advice given to the union by the Fair Work Commissioner, Bernie Riordan. But the Offshore Alliance has accused Chevron of backing away from the recommendations of FWC and failing to provide clarity on some terms of the agreement. Chevron's two facilities in the Pilbara supply about 7% of the world's supply of LNG and about 44% of WA's domestic supply. You can continue reading this story from ABC Pilbara's Rosemary Murphy below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Chevron workers to resume strike at LNG plants in WA's Pilbara on Thursday

featuredLink.title: 'Fed up' workers to continue strikes at Chevron's Pilbara LNG plants

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Last week was a slower one for all things related to economic data, but this week is more than making up for the shortfall. Here's what you can expect to see on the blog throughout the week, or if you want to jot down some dates in your diary (if you're that way inclined â no judgment here!) liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There has been widespread in-principle support for regulating cryptocurrency exchanges and digital asset platforms under the same rules that apply to other financial institutions. The Treasurer Jim Chalmers and Assistant Treasurer Stephen Jones today released a proposal paper that, among other things, recommends requiring crypto platform operators to hold an Australian Financial Services Licence. The government is also planning to implement some additional specific minimum standards for the sector around holding tokens, custody software and transactions. The government says the proposals are broadly in line with regulation in other countries and will give crypto investors better protections against financial loss resulting from the collapse of an exchange. BTC Markets CEO Caroline Bower said her company had already been positioning itself for such regulation. "Digital assets are so clearly the future of financial services. It is imperative the country keeps pace with our international peers, with a robust regulatory framework. "BTC Markets has long agitated for appropriate, proportional regulation of the crypto industry in Australia." The banking sector has also welcomed the move via its lobby group, the Australian Banking Association, whose CEO Anna Bligh said it was a welcome step in the fight against scams. "Almost half of scammed funds are currently being channelled into crypto, the getaway vehicle of choice for scammers," she said. "Once the stolen money reaches a crypto exchange, it is virtually impossible to recover. "This means no matter what financial services door a customer walks through, customers will be protected by the same regulatory standards." The government is inviting feedback on the proposal paper until December 1, with further consultation next year on the resulting draft legislation.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Banks, industry leaders welcome planned cryptocurrency regulation

The banking sector has also welcomed the move via its lobby group, the
Australian Banking Association, whose CEO Anna Bligh
said it was a welcome step in the fight against scams.
"Almost half of scammed funds are currently being channelled into crypto, the getaway vehicle of choice for scammers," she said.
"Once the stolen money reaches a crypto exchange, it is virtually impossible to recover.
"This means no matter what financial services door a customer walks through, customers will be protected by the same regulatory standards."
The government is inviting
feedback on the proposal paper until December 1
, with further consultation next year on the resulting draft legislation.
